# Stephen F. Austin

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about Stephen Fuller Austin, the "Father of Texas". For the
university, see [Stephen F. Austin State
University](/wiki/Stephen_F._Austin_State_University "Stephen F. Austin State
University"). For other uses, see [Stephen Austin
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Stephen_Austin_\(disambiguation\) "Stephen Austin
\(disambiguation\)").

Stephen F. Austin  
---

**Stephen Fuller Austin** (November 3, 1793 – December 27, 1836) was an
American [empresario](/wiki/Empresario "Empresario"). Known as the "**Father
of Texas** ", and the founder of [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas"),[1][2] he led
the second, and ultimately, the successful colonization of the region by
bringing [300 families](/wiki/Old_Three_Hundred "Old Three Hundred") from the
United States to the region in 1825.

Born in [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia") and raised in southeastern
[Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), Austin served in the Missouri
territorial legislature before moving to [Arkansas
Territory](/wiki/Arkansas_Territory "Arkansas Territory") and later
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"). His father, [Moses
Austin](/wiki/Moses_Austin "Moses Austin"), received an empresario grant from
[Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain") to settle Texas. After Moses Austin's death in
1821, Stephen Austin won recognition of the empresario grant from the newly-
independent state of [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). Austin convinced
numerous American settlers to move to Texas, and by 1825 Austin had brought
the first 300 American families into the territory. Throughout the 1820s,
Austin sought to maintain good relations with the Mexican government, and he
helped suppress the [Fredonian Rebellion](/wiki/Fredonian_Rebellion "Fredonian
Rebellion"). He also helped ensure the introduction of [slavery](/wiki/Slavery
"Slavery") into Texas despite the attempts of the Mexican government to ban
the institution.

As Texas settlers became increasingly dissatisfied with the Mexican
government, Austin advocated conciliation with the Mexican government, but the
dissent against Mexico escalated into the [Texas
Revolution](/wiki/Texas_Revolution "Texas Revolution"). Austin led Texas
forces at the successful [Siege of Béxar](/wiki/Siege_of_B%C3%A9xar "Siege of
Béxar") before serving as a commissioner to the United States. Austin ran in
the [1836 Texas presidential
election](/wiki/Republic_of_Texas_presidential_election,_1836 "Republic of
Texas presidential election, 1836") but was defeated by [Sam
Houston](/wiki/Sam_Houston "Sam Houston"). Houston appointed Austin as
secretary of state for the new republic, and Austin held that position until
his death in December 1836.

Numerous places and institutions are named in his honor, including the capital
of Texas, [Austin](/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin, Texas") in [Travis
County](/wiki/Travis_County,_Texas "Travis County, Texas"), [Austin
County](/wiki/Austin_County,_Texas "Austin County, Texas"), [Austin
Bayou](/wiki/Austin_Bayou "Austin Bayou"), [Stephen F. Austin State
University](/wiki/Stephen_F._Austin_State_University "Stephen F. Austin State
University") in [Nacogdoches](/wiki/Nacogdoches,_Texas "Nacogdoches, Texas"),
[Austin College](/wiki/Austin_College "Austin College") in
[Sherman](/wiki/Sherman,_Texas "Sherman, Texas"), and a number of [K-12
schools](/wiki/K-12_schools "K-12 schools").

## Early years

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Austin_Family_Arms.svg/175px-
Austin_Family_Arms.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Austin_Family_Arms.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Austin_Family_Arms.svg "Enlarge")

Coat of arms of Stephen F. Austin

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Monument_to_Stephen_Austin_-
_panoramio.jpg/220px-Monument_to_Stephen_Austin_-
_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Monument_to_Stephen_Austin_-_panoramio.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Monument_to_Stephen_Austin_-_panoramio.jpg "Enlarge")

Memorial to Stephen F. Austin in his birthplace

Stephen F. Austin was born in the [mining](/wiki/Mining "Mining") region of
[southwestern](/wiki/Ordinal_directions "Ordinal directions") Virginia ([Wythe
County](/wiki/Wythe_County,_Virginia "Wythe County, Virginia")) in what is
known as [Austinville](/wiki/Austinville,_Virginia "Austinville, Virginia")
today, some 256 miles (412 km) southwest of [Richmond,
Virginia](/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia "Richmond, Virginia").[3] He was the second
child of [Mary Brown Austin](/wiki/Mary_Brown_Austin "Mary Brown Austin") and
[Moses Austin](/wiki/Moses_Austin "Moses Austin"); the first, Eliza, lived
only one month. On June 8, 1798, when Stephen was four years old, his family
moved west to the lead-mining region of present-day [Potosi,
Missouri](/wiki/Potosi,_Missouri "Potosi, Missouri"), 40 miles west of the
[Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"). His father
Moses Austin received a _sitio_[4] from the Spanish government for the mining
site of _Mine à Breton_ , established by French colonists. His great-great-
grandfather, Anthony Austin (b.1636), was the son of [Richard
Austin](/wiki/Richard_Austin_\(colonist\) "Richard Austin \(colonist\)")
(b.1598 in [Bishopstoke](/wiki/Bishopstoke "Bishopstoke"),
[Hampshire](/wiki/Hampshire "Hampshire"), England), he and his wife Esther
were original settlers of [Suffield,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Suffield,_Massachusetts "Suffield, Massachusetts"), which
became Connecticut in 1749.[5]

When Austin was eleven years old, his family sent him back east to be
educated, first at the preparatory school of [Bacon
Academy](/wiki/Bacon_Academy "Bacon Academy") in [Colchester,
Connecticut](/wiki/Colchester,_Connecticut "Colchester, Connecticut"), and
then at [Transylvania University](/wiki/Transylvania_University "Transylvania
University") in [Lexington, Kentucky](/wiki/Lexington,_Kentucky "Lexington,
Kentucky"), from which he graduated in 1810.[6] After graduation, Austin began
studying to be a lawyer. At age 21, he served in the
[legislature](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature") of the [Missouri
Territory](/wiki/Missouri_Territory "Missouri Territory"). As a member of the
territorial legislature, he was "influential in obtaining a charter for the
struggling Bank of St. Louis."[7]

Left penniless after the [Panic of 1819](/wiki/Panic_of_1819 "Panic of 1819"),
Austin decided to move south to the new [Arkansas
Territory](/wiki/Arkansas_Territory "Arkansas Territory").[6] He acquired
property on the south bank of the Arkansas River, in the area that would later
become [Little Rock](/wiki/Little_Rock,_Arkansas "Little Rock, Arkansas").
After purchasing the property, he learned the area was being considered as the
location for the new territorial capital, which could make his land worth a
great deal more.[8] He made his home in [Hempstead County,
Arkansas](/wiki/Hempstead_County,_Arkansas "Hempstead County, Arkansas"). Two
weeks before the first Arkansas territorial elections in 1820, Austin declared
his candidacy for Congress. His late entrance meant his name did not appear on
the ballot in two of the five counties, but he still placed second in the
field of six candidates. Later, he was appointed as a judge for the First
Circuit Court.[8] Over the next few months, Little Rock did become the
territorial capital, but Austin's claim to land in the area was contested, and
the courts ruled against him. The Territorial Assembly reorganized the
government and abolished Austin's judgeship.[8]

Austin left the territory, moving to [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana").
He reached [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans,_Louisiana "New Orleans,
Louisiana") in November 1820, where he met and stayed with a New Orleans
lawyer and former Kentucky congressman, [Joseph H.
Hawkins](/wiki/Joseph_H._Hawkins "Joseph H. Hawkins"), and made arrangements
to study [law](/wiki/Law "Law").

## Moving to Texas

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/The_Alamo_1936_Issue-3c.jpg/250px-
The_Alamo_1936_Issue-3c.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Alamo_1936_Issue-3c.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Alamo_1936_Issue-3c.jpg "Enlarge")

[Sam Houston](/wiki/Sam_Houston "Sam Houston") and Stephen Austin depicted on
the [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") Centennial Issue [postage
stamp](/wiki/Postage_stamp "Postage stamp") of 1936

During Austin's time in Arkansas, his father traveled to [Spanish
Texas](/wiki/Spanish_Texas "Spanish Texas") and received an
[empresarial](/wiki/Empresario "Empresario") grant that would allow him to
bring 300 American families to Texas,[6] they would be called "[The Old
300](/wiki/Old_Three_Hundred "Old Three Hundred")." Moses Austin caught
pneumonia soon after returning to Missouri.[6] He directed that his
_empresario_ grant would be taken over by his son Stephen.

Although Austin was reluctant to carry on his father's Texas venture, he was
persuaded to pursue the colonization of Texas by a letter from his mother,
[Mary Brown Austin](/wiki/Mary_Brown_Austin "Mary Brown Austin"), written two
days before Moses Austin would die.[9] Austin boarded the steamer, _Beaver_ ,
and departed to New Orleans to meet Spanish officials led by [Erasmo
Seguín](/wiki/Erasmo_Segu%C3%ADn "Erasmo Seguín"). He was at [Natchitoches,
Louisiana](/wiki/Natchitoches,_Louisiana "Natchitoches, Louisiana"), on June
31, 1821, when he learned of his father's death. "This news has effected me
very much, he was one of the most feeling and affectionate Fathers that ever
lived. His faults I now say, and always have, were not of the heart."[10]

At the age of 24, Austin led his party to travel 300 miles (480 km) in four
weeks to [San Antonio](/wiki/San_Antonio "San Antonio") with the intent of
reauthorizing his father's grant, arriving on August 12. While in transit,
they learned Mexico had declared its independence from Spain, and Texas had
become a Mexican province, rather than a Spanish territory. [José Antonio
Navarro](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Antonio_Navarro "José Antonio Navarro"), a San
Antonio native with ambitious visions of the future of Texas, befriended
Stephen F. Austin, and the two developed a lasting association. Navarro,
proficient in Spanish and Mexican law, assisted Austin in obtaining his
empresario contracts.[11] In San Antonio, the grant was reauthorized by
Governor [Antonio María Martínez](/wiki/Antonio_Mar%C3%ADa_Mart%C3%ADnez
"Antonio María Martínez"), who allowed Austin to explore the [Gulf
Coast](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") between [San
Antonio](/wiki/San_Antonio "San Antonio") and the [Brazos
River](/wiki/Brazos_River "Brazos River") to find a suitable location for a
colony.[8] As guides for the party, [Manuel Becerra](/wiki/Manuel_Becerra
"Manuel Becerra") and three [Aranama](/wiki/Aranama "Aranama") Indians, went
with the expedition.

Austin advertised the Texas opportunity in [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans
"New Orleans"), announcing that land was available along the
[Brazos](/wiki/Brazos_River "Brazos River") and
[Colorado](/wiki/Colorado_River_\(Texas\) "Colorado River \(Texas\)")
rivers.[12] A family of a husband, wife, and two children would receive 1,280
acres (520 ha) at twelve and a half cents per acre. Farmers could get 177
acres (72 ha), and ranchers 4,428 acres (1,792 ha). In December 1821, the
first U.S. colonists crossed into the granted territory by land and sea, on
the Brazos River in present-day [Brazoria County,
Texas](/wiki/Brazoria_County,_Texas "Brazoria County, Texas").

## Empresario Austin

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Stephen_Austin_and_dog.jpg/220px-
Stephen_Austin_and_dog.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stephen_Austin_and_dog.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stephen_Austin_and_dog.jpg "Enlarge")

Stephen F. Austin was an important figure in early Texas

Austin's plan for an American colony was thrown into turmoil by Mexico's
gaining [independence from Spain](/wiki/Treaty_of_C%C3%B3rdoba "Treaty of
Córdoba") in 1821. Governor Martínez informed Austin that the _junta
instituyente_ , the new [rump congress](/wiki/Rump_legislature "Rump
legislature") of the government of [Agustín de
Iturbide](/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide "Agustín de Iturbide") of Mexico,
refused to recognize the [land grant](/wiki/Land_grant "Land grant")
authorized by Spain. His government intended to use a general [immigration
law](/wiki/Immigration_law "Immigration law") to regulate new settlement in
Mexico. Austin traveled to [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City"),
where he persuaded the _junta instituyente_ to approve the grant to his
father, as well as the law signed by the Mexican Emperor on January 3, 1823.

The old imperial law offered heads of families a league and a labor of land,
4,605 acres (1,864 ha), and other inducements. It also provided for the
employment of agents, called _[empresarios](/wiki/Empresario "Empresario")_ ,
to promote [immigration](/wiki/Immigration "Immigration"). As an _empresario_
, Austin was to receive 67,000 acres of land for each 200 families he brought
to Texas. According to the law, immigrants were not required to pay fees to
the government. Some of the immigrants denied Austin's right to charge them
for services at the rate of 12.5 cents/acre (31 cents/ha).[13]

When the Emperor of Mexico,[14] [Agustín de
Iturbide](/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide "Agustín de Iturbide"), abdicated in
March 1823, the law was annulled once again. In April 1823, Austin induced the
congress to grant him a contract to bring 300 families into Texas. He wanted
honest, hard-working people who would make the colony a success. In 1824, the
congress passed a [new immigration law](/wiki/General_Colonization_Law
"General Colonization Law") that allowed the individual states of Mexico to
administer public lands and open them to settlement under certain conditions.
In March 1825, the legislature of the Mexican state of [Coahuila y
Tejas](/wiki/Coahuila_y_Tejas "Coahuila y Tejas") passed a law similar to the
one authorized by Iturbide. The law continued the system of _empresarios_ , as
well as granting each married man a league of land, 4,428 acres (1,792 ha),
with the stipulation that he must pay the state $30 within six years.

By late 1825, Austin had brought the first 300 families to his settlement, the
Austin Colony; these 300 are now known in [Texas
history](/wiki/History_of_Texas "History of Texas") as the [Old Three
Hundred](/wiki/Old_Three_Hundred "Old Three Hundred"). Austin had obtained
further contracts to settle an additional 900 families between 1825 and 1829.
He had effective civil and military authority over the
[settlers](/wiki/Settlers "Settlers"), but he was quick to introduce a
semblance of American law - the Constitution of Coahuila y Tejas was agreed on
in November 1827. Also, Austin organized small, informal armed groups to
protect the colonists, which evolved into the [Texas
Rangers](/wiki/Texas_Rangers_Division "Texas Rangers Division"). Despite his
hopes, Austin was making little money from his endeavors; the colonists were
unwilling to pay for his services as _empresario_ and most of his revenues
were spent on the processes of government and other public services.

During these years, Austin, a member of Louisiana Lodge No. 111 at [Ste.
Genevieve, Missouri](/wiki/Ste._Genevieve,_Missouri "Ste. Genevieve,
Missouri"), sought to establish [Freemasonry](/wiki/Freemasonry "Freemasonry")
in Texas. Freemasonry was well established among the educated classes of
Mexican society. It had been introduced among the aristocracy loyal to the
[House of Bourbon](/wiki/House_of_Bourbon "House of Bourbon"), and the
conservatives had total control over the Order. By 1827, Americans living in
[Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City") had introduced the United
States [York Rite](/wiki/York_Rite "York Rite") of Freemasonry as a liberal
alternative to the established European-style [Scottish
Rite](/wiki/Scottish_Rite "Scottish Rite").[15]

On February 11, 1828, Austin called a meeting of Freemasons at [San
Felipe](/wiki/San_Felipe,_Texas "San Felipe, Texas") to elect officers and to
petition the Masonic [Grand Lodge](/wiki/Grand_Lodge "Grand Lodge") in Mexico
City for a charter to form a lodge. Austin was elected [Worshipful
Master](/wiki/Worshipful_Master "Worshipful Master") of the new lodge.
Although the petition reached [Matamoros](/wiki/Matamoros,_Tamaulipas
"Matamoros, Tamaulipas"), and was to be forwarded to Mexico City, nothing more
was heard of it. By 1828, the ruling faction in Mexico was afraid the liberal
elements in Texas might try to gain their independence. Fully aware of the
political philosophies of American Freemasons, the [Mexican
government](/wiki/Mexican_government "Mexican government") outlawed
Freemasonry on October 25, 1828. In 1829, Austin called another meeting, where
it was decided that it was "impolitic and imprudent, at this time, to form
Masonic lodges in Texas."[16]

He was active in promoting trade and currying the good favor of the Mexican
authorities, aiding them in the suppression of the [Fredonian
Rebellion](/wiki/Republic_of_Fredonia "Republic of Fredonia") of [Haden
Edwards](/wiki/Haden_Edwards "Haden Edwards"). Some historians consider the
Fredonian Rebellion to be the beginning of the [Texas
Revolution](/wiki/Texas_Revolution "Texas Revolution"). Although "premature
... the Fredonian Rebellion sparked the powder for later success."[17] For
this event, Austin raised troops to fight with Mexican troops against the
Texas rebels. With the colonists numbering more than 11,000 by 1832, they were
becoming less amenable to Austin's cautious leadership, and also, the Mexican
government was becoming less cooperative. It was concerned with the growth of
the colony and the efforts of the U.S. government to buy the state from them.
The Mexican government had attempted to stop further U.S. immigration as early
as April 1830, but Austin's skills gained an exemption for his colonies. He
granted land to immigrants based on 640 acres (2.6 km2) to the husband, 320 to
the wife, 160 for every child, and 80 for every slave.

## Slavery

Slavery was a very important issue to Austin, one he called "of great
interest" to him.[18] Austin was a periodical slaveowner throughout his life;
however, he had conflicting views about it.[19][20][21][22] Theoretically, he
believed slavery was wrong and went against the American ideal of liberty. In
practice, however, he agreed with the social, economic, and political
justifications of it, and worked hard to defend and expand it.[23] Despite his
defense of it, he also harbored concerns that the long-term effects of slavery
would destroy American society. He grew particularly concerned following [Nat
Turner](/wiki/Nat_Turner "Nat Turner")'s rebellion, stating:

> _" I sometimes shudder at the consequences and think that a large part of
> America will be Santo Domingonized in 100, or 200 years. The idea of seeing
> such a country as this overrun by a slave population almost makes me weep.
> It is in vain to tell a North American that the white population will be
> destroyed some fifty or eighty years hence by the negroes, and that his
> daughters will be violated and Butchered by them.[24][25][26]"_

While Austin thought it would be advantageous some day for Texas to phase out
of slavery, up until the [Texas Revolution](/wiki/Texas_Revolution "Texas
Revolution"), he worked to ensure that his colony's immigrants could bypass
the Mexican government's resistance to it.[27] Doing so ensured the population
growth and economic development of his colony, which was primarily dependent
on the [monocropping](/wiki/Monocropping "Monocropping") of
[cotton](/wiki/Cotton#United_States "Cotton") and sugar.[28][29][30]

Arguing that the loss of slaves would be ruinous to the colony, he arranged
for his settlers to receive eighty acres of land for each slave they brought
with them to Texas. In August 1825, he recommended that the state government
allow immigrants to bring their slaves with them through 1840, with the caveat
that female grandchildren of the slaves would be freed by the age of 15, and
males by age of 25.[31][32][33] His recommendation was rejected.

In 1826, when a state committee proposed abolishing slavery outright, 25
percent of the people in Austin's colony were slaves.[34][35] Austin's
colonists, mostly pro-slavery immigrants from the south, threatened to leave
Texas if the proposition passed, while prospective Southern immigrants
hesitated to come to Texas until slavery was guaranteed there.[33]

Austin conceded that the success of his colony was dependent on
slavery.[19][33][36] Without slaves, the colonists would lack the mass labor
to cultivate the land, which would stall the pace of immigration needed to
develop and increase the value of the land, which would deflate the economy
and motivate his colonists to leave.[33][37][38]

Austin went before the legislature and pleaded that, at the least; his
original 300 colonists should be allowed to keep their slaves.[33] He argued
against the "bad faith" of freeing them, demanded
[reparations](/wiki/Reparations_\(transitional_justice\) "Reparations
\(transitional justice\)") to slaveowners for every slave emancipated by the
state, warned that the loss of slaves could leave some colonists destitute,
and reasoned that freeing them would not only leave his settlers alone in the
harsh Texas environment, but would also expose them to the discomfort and
nuisance of living amongst freed slaves, who would become vagrants seeking
retribution upon their former owners.[39] While he waited for the
legislature's verdict of his request, Austin went into a deep depression over
the issue and sent his brother, [Brown Austin](/wiki/James_E.B._Austin "James
E.B. Austin"), to further lobby the legislature on his behalf.[40][41]

In March of 1827, the legislature signed [Article
13](/wiki/Coahuila_y_Tejas#Immigration_and_slavery "Coahuila y Tejas") into
law. Despite the law complying with some of his requests, Austin called it
"unconstitutional." He contested the law as it freed the children of slaves at
birth, established a six-month grace period before fully emancipating all
slaves in the state, and included provisions to improve the conditions of
slaves and transitioning freedmen.[42][43][44][45] Austin –– who had been so
effective in persuading the legislature, however, that the author of Article
13 (before its passage) requested to withdraw it –– helped his colonists evade
the law by advising them to legally supplant the word "slave" with the words
"workingmen," "family servants," and "laborers," and by working to pass a
decree that banned [freedmen](/wiki/Freedmen "Freedmen") from Texas and forced
emancipated slaves to work for their former slaveowners until the accrued
"debt" (e.g. clothing, food), incurred for their own enslavement, was worked
off.[26][44][46]

In 1828, Austin petitioned the legislature to guarantee that slaveowners,
immigrating to Texas, could legally "free" their slaves before immigrating,
and contract them into a lifetime term of indentured servitude, thereby
avoiding recognizing them as slaves.[47] He lobbied to help his colony elude
[Vicente Guerrero](/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero "Vicente Guerrero")'s 1829 attempt
to legally emancipate slaves in the province, and to bypass the government's
effort to prohibit slavery when it passed the [Law of April 6,
1830](/wiki/Law_of_April_6,_1830 "Law of April 6, 1830").[30][48][49] In 1830,
Austin wrote that he would oppose Texas joining the United States without
guarantees that he should "insist on the perpetual exclusion of slavery from
this state [Texas]."[49] In 1833, he wrote:

> _" Texas must be a slave country. Circumstances and unavoidable necessity
> compel it. It is the wish of the people there, and it is my duty to do all I
> can, prudently, in favor of it. I will do so.[33]"_

In May 1835, Austin's colonists learned that Mexico's tolerance for the
evasions of slaveowners was drawing to a close, with its proposal of new
abolition legislation.[26] Alarmed, and with Austin imprisoned in Mexico for
pushing for independence, colonists turned against the Mexican government,
calling it "oppressive" and a "plundering, robbing, autocratical government"
without regard for the security of "life, liberty or property."[26][50]
Resisting the impact a changed slavery policy would have on economic growth,
and fearing rumors of Mexico's plan to free the slaves and turn them loose
upon the colonists, shortly after Austin returned from Mexico, he and his
colonists took up arms against the Mexican government. Austin later gained
U.S. Government support for his revolution when he wrote to Senator [Lewis F.
Linn](/wiki/Lewis_F._Linn "Lewis F. Linn") and pleaded that [Santa
Anna](/wiki/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna "Antonio López de Santa Anna")
planned to "exterminate" all of the colonists and fill Texas "with Indians and
negroes [freed slaves]."[26][51][52]

## Relations with Mexico

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/da/Stephen_F._Austin_at_the_Texas_State_Capitol.jpg/220px-
Stephen_F._Austin_at_the_Texas_State_Capitol.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stephen_F._Austin_at_the_Texas_State_Capitol.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stephen_F._Austin_at_the_Texas_State_Capitol.jpg "Enlarge")

Marble sculpture of Stephen F. Austin (1903) by [Elisabet
Ney](/wiki/Elisabet_Ney "Elisabet Ney") at the Texas State Capitol

The application off the immigration control of the introduction of
[tariff](/wiki/Tariff "Tariff") laws had done much to dissatisfy the
colonists, peaking in the [Anahuac Disturbances](/wiki/Anahuac_Disturbances
"Anahuac Disturbances"). Austin became involved in Mexican politics,
supporting the upstart [Antonio López de Santa
Anna](/wiki/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna "Antonio López de Santa Anna").
Following the success of Santa Anna, the colonists sought a compensatory
reward, proclaimed at the [Convention of 1832](/wiki/Convention_of_1832
"Convention of 1832")—resumption of immigration, tariff exemption, separation
from Coahuila, and a new state government for Texas. Austin did not support
these demands; he considered them ill-timed and tried his hardest to moderate
them. When they were repeated and extended at the [Convention of
1833](/wiki/Convention_of_1833 "Convention of 1833"), Austin traveled to
[Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City") on July 18, 1833, and met with
Vice President [Valentín Gomez Farías](/wiki/Valent%C3%ADn_Gomez_Far%C3%ADas
"Valentín Gomez Farías"). Austin did gain certain important reforms; the
immigration ban was lifted, but a separate state government was not
authorized. Statehood in Mexico required a population of 80,000, and Texas had
only 30,000.

Believing that he was pushing for Texas independence and suspect that he was
trying to incite insurrection, Austin was arrested by the Mexican government
in January 1834 in [Saltillo](/wiki/Saltillo "Saltillo"),
[Coahuila](/wiki/Coahuila "Coahuila"), [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). He was
taken to [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City") and imprisoned. No
charges were filed against him as no court would take jurisdiction. He was
moved from prison to prison. He was released under bond in December 1834 and
required to stay in the [Federal District](/wiki/Federal_District "Federal
District"). He was fully freed under the general amnesty in July 1835 and in
August 1835 left Mexico to return to Texas via [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans
"New Orleans").

## Texas Revolution

Main article: [Texas Revolution](/wiki/Texas_Revolution "Texas Revolution")

In his absence, a number of events propelled the colonists toward
confrontation with Santa Anna's centralist government. Austin took temporary
command of the Texan forces during the [Siege of
Béxar](/wiki/Siege_of_B%C3%A9xar "Siege of Béxar") from October 12 to December
11, 1835. After learning of the [Disturbances at
Anahuac](/wiki/Anahuac_Disturbances "Anahuac Disturbances") and Velasco in the
summer of 1835, an enraged Santa Anna made rapid preparations for the Mexican
army to sweep Anglo settlers from Texas. War began in October 1835 at
[Gonzales](/wiki/Gonzales,_Texas "Gonzales, Texas"). The [Republic of
Texas](/wiki/Republic_of_Texas "Republic of Texas"), created by a new
constitution on March 2, 1836, won independence following a string of defeats
with the dramatic turnabout victory at the [Battle of San
Jacinto](/wiki/Battle_of_San_Jacinto "Battle of San Jacinto") on April 21,
1836, and the capture of Santa Anna the following morning. He was then
imprisoned.

## Austin in the Republic of Texas

Further information: [Republic of Texas](/wiki/Republic_of_Texas "Republic of
Texas")

In December 1835, Austin, Branch Archer, and [William H.
Wharton](/wiki/William_H._Wharton "William H. Wharton") were appointed
commissioners to the U.S. by the provisional government of the republic. On
June 10, 1836, Austin was in New Orleans, where he received word of Santa
Anna's defeat by [Sam Houston](/wiki/Sam_Houston "Sam Houston") at the [Battle
of San Jacinto](/wiki/Battle_of_San_Jacinto "Battle of San Jacinto"). Austin
returned to Texas to rest at Peach Point in August. On August 4, he announced
his candidacy for president of Texas. Austin felt confident he could win the
election until two weeks before the election, when on August 20, Houston
entered the race. Austin wrote, "Many of the old settlers who are too blind to
see or understand their interest will vote for him." Houston carried East
Texas, the Red River region, and most of the soldiers' votes. Austin received
587 votes to [Sam Houston](/wiki/Sam_Houston "Sam Houston")'s 5,119 and [Henry
Smith](/wiki/Henry_Smith_\(Texas_Governor\) "Henry Smith \(Texas
Governor\)")'s 743 votes.

Houston would appoint Austin as the first secretary of state of the new
republic; however, Austin only served approximately two months before his
death.

## Death and estate

In December 1836, Austin was in the new capital of Columbia (now known as
[West Columbia](/wiki/West_Columbia,_Texas "West Columbia, Texas")) where he
caught a severe cold; his condition worsened. Doctors were called in, but
could not help him. Austin died of [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia") at
noon on December 27, 1836. He was at the home of George B. McKinstry, near
what is now West Columbia, Texas. He was 43. Austin's last words were "The
independence of Texas is recognized! Don't you see it in the papers?..." Upon
hearing of Austin's death, Houston ordered an official statement proclaiming:
"The Father of Texas is no more; the first pioneer of the wilderness has
departed." Originally, Austin was buried at [Gulf Prairie
Cemetery](/wiki/Gulf_Prairie_Cemetery "Gulf Prairie Cemetery") in [Brazoria
County, Texas](/wiki/Brazoria_County,_Texas "Brazoria County, Texas"). In 1910
Austin's body was reinterred at the [Texas State
Cemetery](/wiki/Texas_State_Cemetery "Texas State Cemetery") in
[Austin](/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin, Texas").

Austin never married, nor did he have any children. He bequeathed all his
land, titles, and possessions, to his married sister, [Emily Austin
Perry](/wiki/Emily_Austin_Perry "Emily Austin Perry").

  * [Sherman](/wiki/Sherman,_Texas "Sherman, Texas"), Texas, is the home of [Austin College](/wiki/Austin_College "Austin College").[53]
  * [Nacogdoches, Texas](/wiki/Nacogdoches,_Texas "Nacogdoches, Texas"), is the home of [Stephen F. Austin State University](/wiki/Stephen_F._Austin_State_University "Stephen F. Austin State University").[54]
  * Both [Austin, Texas](/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin, Texas"), and [Austin County, Texas](/wiki/Austin_County,_Texas "Austin County, Texas"), are named after Stephen F. Austin, however, Austin (the city) is not located in Austin (the county).[55] (Austin, Texas is located in Travis County).[55]
  * [Angleton, Texas](/wiki/Angleton,_Texas "Angleton, Texas"), features a statue of Austin,[56] sponsored by The Stephen F. Austin 500, sculpted by David Adickes, with a base of 12-feet and a total statue height of 72-feet. The base is 2-feet taller than the base of the Sam Houston statue in Huntsville, Texas, but the statue is 7-feet shorter. The Sam Houston statue is 67-feet, on a base of 10-feet, or 77-feet if you include statue and base.
  * The [National Statuary Hall Collection](/wiki/National_Statuary_Hall_Collection "National Statuary Hall Collection") permits each state to select just two statues for display at the Capital in Washington, D.C. Texas selected Sam Houston and Stephen F. Austin; these statues were sculpted by German immigrant [Elisabet Ney](/wiki/Elisabet_Ney "Elisabet Ney").[57]
  * [Gulf Prairie Cemetery](/wiki/Gulf_Prairie_Cemetery "Gulf Prairie Cemetery"), his original place of burial.[58]
  * In 1959, Austin was [posthumously](/wiki/Posthumous_recognition "Posthumous recognition") inducted into the [Hall of Great Westerners](/wiki/Hall_of_Great_Westerners "Hall of Great Westerners") at the [National Cowboy Hall of Fame](/wiki/National_Cowboy_Hall_of_Fame "National Cowboy Hall of Fame") in [Oklahoma City](/wiki/Oklahoma_City,_Oklahoma "Oklahoma City, Oklahoma"), [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma").
  * In Austinville, [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"), Austin's birthplace, a monument was erected along the New River near a junction with the [New River Trail State Park](/wiki/New_River_Trail_State_Park "New River Trail State Park").
  * In [Bellville, Texas](/wiki/Bellville,_Texas "Bellville, Texas"), the county seat of Austin County, a large bust of Austin by sculptor David Adickes is located at the intersection of State Highways 36 and 159.

The late actor [John Carter](/wiki/John_Carter_\(actor\) "John Carter
\(actor\)") played Austin in the 1969 episode "Here Stands Bailey" of the
[syndicated](/wiki/Television_syndication "Television syndication")
[television series](/wiki/Television_series "Television series") _[Death
Valley Days](/wiki/Death_Valley_Days "Death Valley Days")_ , hosted by [Robert
Taylor](/wiki/Robert_Taylor_\(actor\) "Robert Taylor \(actor\)") not long
before Taylor's own death. In the story line, the hardy, cantankerous pioneer
[James Briton "Brit" Bailey](/wiki/Bailey%27s_Prairie,_Texas "Bailey's
Prairie, Texas") ([Paul Fix](/wiki/Paul_Fix "Paul Fix")) and his wife, Hannah
([Rosemary DeCamp](/wiki/Rosemary_DeCamp "Rosemary DeCamp")), make their final
settlement in southeastern [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") after having overcome
many obstacles over the years. Now they face Austin's order that they leave
their land, however, Austin has a change of heart and asks them to stay.
Bailey dies with his final wish of interment standing upright facing west,
hence his grave marker, "Here Stands Bailey Facing West."[59]

## Past family

While Stephen F. Austin and his sister Emily have each been subject of
biography, they are descended from several generations of noteworthy people,
including: [Moses Austin](/wiki/Moses_Austin "Moses Austin") (father—biography
published by Trinity University Press),[60] [Abia Brown](/wiki/Abia_Brown
"Abia Brown") (grandfather), [Joseph Sharp](/wiki/Joseph_Sharp "Joseph Sharp")
(great grandfather), [Isaac Sharp](/wiki/Isaac_Sharp "Isaac Sharp") (great,
great grandfather), [Anthony Sharp](/wiki/Anthony_Sharp_\(Quaker\) "Anthony
Sharp \(Quaker\)") (great, great, great grandfather—biography published by
Stanford University Press).[61] Accordingly, history records noteworthy social
contribution in each generation of Stephen's family dating back to the early
seventeenth century.
